data.text:
Get ready to explore the cinematic journey of Elpidia Carrillo, a talented actress known for her compelling performances in multiple movies! In this engaging roundup article, we’ll dive into the world of Elpidia Carrillo’s movies, showcasing her versatility and range as a performer. From her earliest roles to her most recent projects, join us on a captivating journey through Elpidia Carrillo’s filmography!

As an Amazon™ Associate, we earn from qualifying purchases.

1. Pafnucio Santo (1977)

Pafnucio Santo is an intriguing and provocative 1977 Mexican drama that brings together history, surrealism, and a dash of the unexpected. The film, directed by Rafael Corkidi, follows the journey of a messenger who encounters a series of historical events and influential figures, including Auschwitz, the Ku Klux Klan, Frida Kahlo, Cortés, and Emiliano Zapata.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

2. Pedro Páramo (1977)

Pedro Páramo” is a gripping three-hour drama film directed by José Bolaños and based on the 1967 literary adaptation by Juan Rulfo. Set in a mysterious arid village, the movie revolves around a wayfarer who embarks on a journey to meet the father who long ago abandoned his wife. The haunting exploration of the village, its secrets, and the search for redemption draw the viewer into a captivating narrative filled with unexpected twists and intrigue.

3. Deseos (1977)

Deseos, “ directed by Rafael Corkidi, is a captivating 1977 drama set in a small, depressing village. The story revolves around a rebellious son, his desperate father searching for their lost love, and a jaded ex-lover. This surreal tale comes to life with bold visuals and statements about sin.

4. Nuevo mundo (1978)

Nuevo mundo, “ a gripping 1978 Mexican drama by Gabriel Retes, takes viewers on a historical journey set in 16th-century Mexico. This captivating tale revolves around a priest who transforms the life of a community by miraculously creating an image of the Virgin Mary reminiscent of a local native woman. The movie dives into the themes of Christianization, culture clash, and religious violence in an era of extreme transformation.

Bandera rota, “ a 1979 Mexican neo-noir crime drama, weaves a tale of accusation, mistake, and blackmail. Directed by Gabriel Retes, the film follows the story of a man who stumbles into a dangerous game of mistaken identity and finds himself in the crosshairs of a relentless investigation.

Chicoasén” is an immersive action-packed adventure drama set in the early 80s against a backdrop of political corruption and cultural conflict. The film, released in August 1980, is directed by Rafael Baledón, Javier Durán, and Francisco Guerrero, with a script penned by the talented trio of Rafael Baledón, Mario Ezcurdia, and Xavier Robles.

8. Under Fire (1983)

In the dramatic and gripping film “Under Fire” (1983), renowned actors Nick Nolte, Ed Harris, and Gene Hackman brilliantly portray three journalists navigating a complex romantic triangle while entangled in the political intrigue of the last days of the Somozoa regime in Nicaragua. As the nation steadily approaches its popular revolution in 1979, this powerful trio encounters a dangerous whirlwind of revolutionary fervor, corrupt regimes, and personal struggles.

9. Beyond the Limit (1983)

Beyond the Limit, “ a 1983 drama-romance thriller set in Argentina during the Dirty War, follows the life of a half-English doctor who befriends various factions involving the police, rebels, and alcoholic Honorary British Consul. As tensions rise, the consul is mistakenly kidnapped by the rebels, and he must choose a side, leading to a thrilling hostage situation.

11. Bartolome oder Die Rückkehr der weißen Götter (1985)

Bartolome oder Die Rückkehr der weißen Götter” (1985) is a compelling drama that intertwines historical elements with fictional dialogue. The film focuses on a young Indian Dominican who engages in a conversation with Dominican Bishop Bartolomé de Las Casas. Set in the 16th century, this bishop passionately opposed the conquistadors, making him a prominent figure in the fight against colonialism.

14. Predator (1987)

Predator” is an exhilarating 1987 action-adventure film directed by John McTiernan and written by Jim Thomas and John Thomas. Set in the dense and treacherous terrain of the Central American jungle, the film follows a team of commandos on a high-stakes mission gone awry. As they navigate a guerrilla base and attempt to carry out their orders, the team faces a terrifying new foe: an extraterrestrial warrior hell-bent on hunting them down.

The Assassin” is a tense and thrilling action movie from 1990, starring Steve Railsback and Elpidia Carrillo. The film follows a story of political intrigue and government conspiracies, unveiled by a CIA agent who swears to protect a vulnerable senator. The twist? Dangerous Passion, released in 1990, is a high-octane action-crime thriller that will leave you on the edge of your seat. Carl Weathers stars as a dedicated security man, landing a job with the charismatic but ruthless gangster, Billy Dee Williams. The two worlds collide as Weathers forms an instant connection with the gangster’s beguiling wife, Lonette McKee.

17. Predator 2 (1990)

Predator 2" takes the terrifying story of the eponymous creatures and transplants it onto the grim, chaotic streets of a future Los Angeles in a state of war. Danny Glover, in a gritty performance, plays Mike Harrigan, a grizzled police lieutenant who must confront the ruthless extra-terrestrial hunter in the city’s midst. Gary Busey, Kevin Peter Hall, and an ensemble of skilled action performers join Glover in this thrilling sci-fi sequel.

18. Lightning Field (1991)

Lightning Field” (1991) is a supernatural, action-packed thriller where a desperate mother, Nancy McKeon’s character, uncovers undiscovered psychic powers after her baby is stolen by the twisted clutches of a devil-worshipping cult. She embarks on a harrowing journey to track down her precious little one.

19. Ciudad de ciegos (1991)

Ciudad de ciegos” is a powerful, evocative drama that takes place in a small neighborhood in Mexico City over the course of more than 30 years. Directed by Alberto Cortés and written by José Agustín, Hernann Bellinghaussen, and himself, the film is a compelling exploration of solitude and the changing world around us. As the city’s inhabitants come and go, the only constant remains the disruption in their lives. The set itself serves as a metaphor for the city, showing only the outside world through the windows and the transient objects brought by the characters. Featuring memorable performances from Gabriela Roel, Arcelia Ramírez, and Verónica Merchant, “Ciudad de ciegos” is a poignant and thought-provoking journey that masterfully blends drama, intrigue, and emotion.

20. La hija del Puma (1994)

La hija del Puma, a riveting drama released in 1994, takes viewers on a heart-wrenching journey through the turbulent times of Guatemala’s human rights crisis. The film is narrated by a courageous young indigenous woman who has witnessed a horrifying massacre in her Central American homeland. As she courageously shares her story, we are given a poignant and unforgettable insight into the devastating impact of war on innocent lives.

21. My Family/Mi familia (1995)

My Family, “ also known as “Mi familia, “ is a deeply moving and visually stunning drama film that explores the lives of a Mexican family as they navigate their way from the 1920s in Mexico to the bustling streets of Los Angeles in the 1960s. The story focuses on the children of the family, their journeys, and the challenges they face as they grow up and start their own families.

22. The Brave (1997)

The Brave, “ a 1997 drama film, follows the story of a struggling American Indian man, recently released from jail. When he’s presented with the opportunity to star in a snuff film, he’s faced with a difficult choice: risk his life for his family’s financial well-being or walk away, leaving them in poverty. Directed by Johnny Depp, with a screenplay penned by him alongside Gregory McDonald and Paul McCudden, the film stars Depp, Marlon Brando, and Marshall Bell.

24. They Come at Night (1998)

In the gritty streets of 1986 Los Angeles, young and resilient Celeste (Elpidia Carrillo), an illegal immigrant from El Salvador, faces a daunting task of trying to make a life in a new country. Traumatized by past abuses and separated from her family, Celeste strives to find her place amidst the chaos of the city’s underground world. As she navigates through these challenging times, she is forced to confront her past and decide whether to turn a new leaf or fall back into old habits. “They Come at Night” is an intense drama that takes an intimate look into the life of a courageous young woman and her desperate attempts to build a better future.

25. Un embrujo (1998)

Un embrujo, “ a captivating drama-romance film released in 1999, is set in 1930s Mexico where passion and innocence collide. Directed by Carlos Carrera, the movie follows a young boy who falls deeply in love with his female elementary-school teacher, set against the backdrop of their rural Mexican community. This beautifully crafted story delves into the complexities of first love, the societal pressures of the time, and the emotional consequences for those involved.

26. Things You Can Tell Just by Looking at Her (2000)

Things You Can Tell Just by Looking at Her” explores the complex lives of five Californian women, each dealing with their own unique and heart-wrenching personal issues. As their paths collide in unforeseeable ways, the boundaries between love, friendship, and self-discovery are pushed to the limits. With gripping performances from Glenn Close, Cameron Diaz, and Calista Flockhart, this drama-romance film is a poignant journey through the emotional struggles faced by women in contemporary society.

27. Bread and Roses (2000)

Bread and Roses, “ a powerful drama from 2000, tells the inspiring story of two hardworking Latina sisters who toil as cleaners in a bustling downtown office building. As they fight for the rights of unionization and better working conditions, they experience the triumphs and tribulations of their struggle. Directed by Ken Loach and written by Paul Laverty, this thought-provoking film presents a powerful commentary on justice, the importance of unions, and the fight for fair wages.

28. Solaris (2002)

In the vast expanse of space, a troubled psychologist named Kris Kelvin is sent on a mission to investigate the crew of an isolated research station orbiting a mysterious planet called Solaris. 29. A Day Without a Mexican (2004)

Imagine a world where the Mexicans disappear, and your life crumbles around you. That’s the basis for Sergio Arau’s fantastic, whimsical film, ‘A Day Without a Mexican’. Set in 2004, the story follows a mysterious fog that surrounds the boundaries of California, causing a communication breakdown and, consequently, the disappearance of all Mexicans. The repercussions are felt across the state’s economy and daily life, as the absence of Mexican workers and dwellers halts the functioning of the state.

Thieves and Liars” is a gripping, crime drama film set in Puerto Rico, exploring the struggles faced by three families as they battle against the corrupt and drug-infested society. 37. Relentless (2018)

In the gripping 2018 thriller “Relentless, “ an American mother embarks on a harrowing journey to find her missing daughter, who has been kidnapped by a ruthless Central American gang involved in human trafficking. As the stakes grow higher and the odds of survival seem bleak, the mother must face her darkest fears and confront the horrifying reality of a world where innocence is commodified. Starring Sydney Sweeney, Elpidia Carrillo, and Courtenay Taylor, “Relentless” masterfully weaves a tale of survival, hope, and the desperate lengths one will go to for their loved ones.
